24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything27:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything28:T72d,<entryFree id="n30347" key="عِلْمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عِلْمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> is an inf. n., (S, K, &amp;c.,) and [as such] has no pl. [in the classical language]. (Sb, TA voce <foreign lang="ar">فِكْرٌ</foreign>.) [As a post-classical term, used as a simple subst., its pl. is <foreign lang="ar">عُلُومٌ</foreign>, signifying The <hi rend="ital">sciences,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">several species of knowledge.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Sometimes it is applied to <hi rend="ital">Predominant opinion;</hi> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">preponderant belief;</hi>] because it stands in stead of that which is <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign> properly so termed. (Ham p. 632.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And sometimes it is used in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">عَمَلٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A doing,</hi> &amp;c.], as mentioned by Az, on the authority of Ibn-'Oyeyneh, agreeably with an explanation of <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign> as signifying one “ who does according to his knowledge; ” and it has been expl. as having this meaning in the Kur xii. 68 [where the primary meaning seems to be much more apposite]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">لَقِيتُهُ أَدْنَى عِلْمٍ</foreign> means [<hi rend="ital">I met him the first thing,</hi> like <foreign lang="ar">لقيته أَدْنَى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دَنِّىِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَدْنَى دَنًا</foreign>; or] <hi rend="ital">before everything</hi> [<hi rend="ital">else</hi>]. (TA.)    </entryFree>29:T16d4,<entryFree id="n30348" key="عَلَمٌ" type="main">

                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَلَمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see <foreign lang="ar">عَلَامَةٌ</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">An impression,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">impress;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a footstep,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">track,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">trace.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And The <foreign lang="ar">عَلَم</foreign> of a garment, or piece of cloth; (S;) [i. e. the <hi rend="ital">ornamental,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">figured,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">variegated, border</hi> or <hi rend="ital">borders</hi> thereof;] the <hi rend="ital">figured,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">variegated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">embroidered, work</hi> or <hi rend="ital">decoration,</hi> (Msb, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">in the borders,</hi> (TA,) thereof: (Msb, K, TA:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامٌ</foreign>. (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And [<hi rend="ital">A way-mark;</hi> i. e.] <hi rend="ital">a thing set up,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">erected, in the way,</hi> (K, TA,) or, as in the M, <hi rend="ital">in the deserts,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">waterless deserts,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">for guidance,</hi> (K, TA,) in the M, <hi rend="ital">for the guidance of those going astray;</hi> (TA;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30348-1" target="عَلَامَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30358"/></foreign>: (K:) the former is also applied to <hi rend="ital">a building raised in the beaten track of the road, of such as are places of alighting for travellers, whereby one is guided to the land</hi> [<hi rend="ital">that is the object of a journey</hi>]: pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامٌ</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمٌ</foreign> also signifies <hi rend="ital">a</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَنَارَة</foreign> [app. a mistranscription for <foreign lang="ar">مَنَار</foreign>, without <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>: see these two words]. (TA. [See also <foreign lang="ar">مَعْلَمٌ</foreign>.]) [Hence, <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامُ الكَوَاكِبِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The stars,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">asterisms, that are signs of the way to travellers:</hi> see <foreign lang="ar">مِصْبَاحٌ</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">A separation between two lands;</hi> [like <foreign lang="ar">مَنَارٌ</foreign>;] as also

                  <hi rend="ital">The limits that are set to the Sacred Territory.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">A mountain;</hi> (S, K;) as a general term: or <hi rend="ital">a long mountain:</hi> (K:) [app. as forming a separation: or as being a known sign of the way:] pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عِلَامٌ</foreign>: (K:) the former pl. occurring in the Kur [xlii. 31 and] lv. 24. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">A banner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">standard,</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">رَايَةٌ</foreign>, (S, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">to which the soldiers congregate:</hi> (TA:) and, (K,) some say, (TA,) the <hi rend="ital">thing</hi> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">flag,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strip of cloth,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">that is tied upon the spear:</hi> (K, TA:) it occurs in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee with the second fet-hah lengthened by an alif after it [so that it becomes   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30348-3" target="عَلَام" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>]. (IJ, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  And <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  The <hi rend="ital">chief of a people</hi> or <hi rend="ital">party:</hi> (K, TA:) from the same word as signifying “ a mountain ” or “ a banner: ” (TA:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامٌ</foreign>. (K.)          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  [In grammar, it signifies <hi rend="ital">A proper name</hi> of a person or place &amp;c.          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  And the pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَامٌ</foreign> is applied to <hi rend="ital">Things pertaining to rites and ceremonies</hi> of the pilgrimage or the like, <hi rend="ital">as being signs</hi> thereof; such as the <hi rend="ital">places where such rites and ceremonies are performed,</hi> the <hi rend="ital">beasts destined for sacrifice,</hi> and the <hi rend="ital">various practices performed during the pilgrimage &amp;c.;</hi> as also <foreign lang="ar">مَعَالِمُ</foreign>, pl. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30348-4" target="مَعْلَمٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30371"/></foreign>: the former word is applied to such places in the Ksh and Bd and the Jel in ii. 153; and the latter, in the Ksh and Bd in ii. 194: the former is also applied to the beasts destined for sacrifice in the Ksh and Bd and the Jel in xxii. 37; and the latter, in the Ksh and Bd in xxii. 33: and both are applied to the practices above mentioned, the former in the TA and the latter in the K, in art. <foreign lang="ar">شعر</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">شِعَارٌ</foreign>.]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also what next follows.    </entryFree>2a:T856,<entryFree id="n30368" key="أَعْلَمُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَعْلَمُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">More,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">most, knowing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">learned</hi>]. Applied to God, [it may often be rendered <hi rend="ital">Supreme in knowledge:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">omniscient:</hi> but often, in this case,] it means [simply]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30368-1" target="عَالِمٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30365"/></foreign> [in the sense of <hi rend="ital">knowing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cognizant</hi>]. (Jel in iii. 31, and I'Ak p. 240.) [Therefore <foreign lang="ar">اَللّٰهُ أَعْلَمُ</foreign> virtually means, sometimes, <hi rend="ital">God knows best;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">knows all things:</hi> and sometimes, simply, <hi rend="ital">God knows.</hi>]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also [<hi rend="ital">Harelipped;</hi> i. e.] <hi rend="ital">having a fissure in his upper lip:</hi> (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or <hi rend="ital">in one of its two sides:</hi> (K:) the camel is said to be <foreign lang="ar">اعلم</foreign> because of the fissure in his upper lip: when the fissure is in the lower lip, the epithet <foreign lang="ar">أَفْلَحُ</foreign> is used: and <foreign lang="ar">أَشْرَمُ</foreign> is used in both of these, and also in other, similar, senses: (TA:) the fem. of <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَمُ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">عَلْمَآءُ</foreign>: (S, Msb, TA:) which is likewise applied to a lip (<foreign lang="ar">شَفَةٌ</foreign>). (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">العَلْمَآءُ</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">The coat of mail:</hi> (K:) mentioned by Sh, in the book entitled <foreign lang="ar">كِتَابُ السِّلَاحِ</foreign>; but as not heard by him except in a verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Khabbáb [?]. (TA.)    </entryFree>2b:T378f,<entryFree id="n30340" key="عَلِمَهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَلِمَهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">عَلَمَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عِلْمٌ</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">He knew it;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, acquainted with it;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">عَرَفَهُ</foreign>: (S, K:) or <hi rend="ital">he knew it</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">عَرَفَهُ</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">truly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">certainly:</hi> (B, TA:) by what is said above, and by what is afterwards said in the K, <foreign lang="ar">العِلْمُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">المَعْرِفَةُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">الشُّعُورُ</foreign> are made to have one meaning; and this is nearly what is said by most of the lexicologists: but most of the critics discriminate every one of these from the others; and <foreign lang="ar">العِلْمُ</foreign>, accord. to them, denotes the highest quality, because it is that which they allow to be an attribute of God; whereas they did not say [that He is] <foreign lang="ar">عَارِفٌ</foreign>, in the most correct language, nor <foreign lang="ar">شَاعِرٌ</foreign>: (TA:) [respecting other differences between <foreign lang="ar">العِلْم</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">المَعْرِفَة</foreign>, the former of which is more general in signification than the latter, see the first paragraph of art. <foreign lang="ar">عرف</foreign>: much might be added to what is there stated on that subject, and in explanation of <foreign lang="ar">العِلْم</foreign>, from the TA, but not without controversy:] or <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ</foreign> signifies <foreign lang="ar">تَيَقَّنَ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">he knew</hi> a thing, <hi rend="ital">intuitively,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">inferentially,</hi> as expl. in the Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">يقن</foreign>]; <foreign lang="ar">العِلْمُ</foreign> being syn. with <foreign lang="ar">اليَقِينُ</foreign>; but it occurs with the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">الَمَعْرِفَةُ</foreign>, like as <foreign lang="ar">المَعْرِفَةُ</foreign> occurs with the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">العلْمُ</foreign>, each being made to import the meaning of the other because each is preceded by ignorance [when not attributed to God]: Zuheyr says, [in his Mo'allakah,] <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَأَعْلَمُ عِلْمَ اليَوْمِ وَٱلْأَمْسِ قَبْلَهُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَلٰكِنِّنِى عَنْ عِلْمِ مَا فِى غَدٍ عَمِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> meaning <foreign lang="ar">وَأَعْرِفُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">And I know the knowledge of the present day, and of yesterday before it; but to the knowledge of what will be to-morrow I am blind</hi>]: and it is said in the Kur [viii. 62], <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَعْلَمُونَهُمْ اَللّٰهُ يَعْلَمُهُمْ</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَعْرِفُونَهُمْ اَللّٰهُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَعْرِفُهُمْ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Ye know them not,</hi> but <hi rend="ital">God knoweth them</hi>]; <foreign lang="ar">المَعْرِفَة</foreign> being attributed to God because it is one of the two kinds of <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign>, [the intuitive and the inferential,] and the discrimination between them is conventional, on account of their different dependencies, though He is declared to be free from the imputation of antecedent ignorance and from acquisition [of knowledge], for He knows what has been and what will be and how that which will not be would be if it were, his <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign> being an eternal and essential attribute: when <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ</foreign> denotes <foreign lang="ar">اليَقِين</foreign>, it [sometimes] has two objective complements; but as syn. with <foreign lang="ar">عَرَفَ</foreign>, it has a single objective complement: (Msb:) it has two objective complements in the saying, in the Kur [lx. 10], <foreign lang="ar">فَإِنْ عَلِمْتُمُوهُنَّ مُؤْمِنَاتٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And</hi> 
                  <pb n="2139"/> 
                  <hi rend="ital">if ye know them to be believers</hi>]; and [in like manner] they allowed one's saying <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُنِى</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">I knew myself to be</hi>], like as they said <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُنِى</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">حَسِبْتُنِى</foreign> &amp;c.: (TA:) and sometimes it imports the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">شَعَرَ</foreign>, and is therefore followed by <foreign lang="ar">بِ</foreign>: (Msb:) [thus] <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ بِهِ</foreign> signifies <foreign lang="ar">شَعَرَ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">شَعُرَ</foreign> (accord. to different copies of the K) [i. e. <hi rend="ital">He knew it;</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">he knew,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">understood it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he knew the minute particulars of it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he perceived it by means of any of the senses:</hi> and sometimes this means <hi rend="ital">he became informed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">apprised, of it:</hi> and sometimes, <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, knowing in it</hi>]: or in this case, [as meaning <foreign lang="ar">شَعَرْتُ بِهِ</foreign>,] you say, <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُ بِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I knew it;</hi> &amp;c.]: (Msb:) and one says, <foreign lang="ar">مَا عَلِمْتُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِخَبَرِ قُدُومِهِ</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">مَا شَعَرْتُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I knew not,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">the tidings of his coming,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">arrival</hi>]. (TA.)   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30340-1" target="اعتلمهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30344"/></foreign>, also, signifies <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He knew it;</hi> &amp;c.]. (K.) And one says   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30340-2" target="تَعَلَّمْ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> in the place of <foreign lang="ar">اِعْلَمْ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Know thou;</hi> &amp;c.]: ISk says, <foreign lang="ar">تَعَلَّمْتُ أَنَّ فُلَانًا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">خَارِجٌ</foreign> is a phrase used in the place of <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُ</foreign> [as meaning <hi rend="ital">I knew,</hi> or, emphatically, <hi rend="ital">I know, that such a one was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">is, going forth</hi>]; adding, [however,] when it is said to thee, <foreign lang="ar">اِعْلَمْ أَنَّ زَيْدًا خَارِجٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Know thou that Zeyd is going forth</hi>], thou sayest <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ عَلِمْتُ</foreign> [lit. <hi rend="ital">I have known,</hi> meaning <hi rend="ital">I do know</hi>]; but when it is said, <foreign lang="ar">تَعَلَّمْ أَنَّ زَيْدًا خَارِجٌ</foreign>, thou dost not say, <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ تَعَلَّمْتُ</foreign>; (S:) accord. to IB, these two verbs are not used as syn. except in the imperative forms: (TA:) [or] <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ الأَمْرَ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30340-3" target="تَعَلَّمَهُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> are syn. as signifying <foreign lang="ar">أَتْقَنَهُ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">he knew,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">learned, the case,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair, soundly, thoroughly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">well:</hi> see art. <foreign lang="ar">تقن</foreign>: but I think it not improbable, though I do not find it in any copy of the K, that the right reading may be <foreign lang="ar">أَيْقَنَهُ</foreign>, which is syn. with <foreign lang="ar">تَيَقَّنَهُ</foreign>; an explanation of <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ</foreign> in the Msb, as mentioned above, being <foreign lang="ar">تَيَقَّنَ</foreign>]. (K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30340-4" target="تعالمهُ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n30342"/>الجَمِيعُ</foreign> means <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمُوهُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">All knew him;</hi> &amp;c.]. (S, K.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُ عِلْمَهُ</foreign> [lit. <hi rend="ital">I knew his knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">what he knew,</hi> app. meaning <hi rend="ital">I tried, proved,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tested, him, and so knew what he knew;</hi> and hence <hi rend="ital">I knew his case</hi> or <hi rend="ital">state</hi> or <hi rend="ital">condition,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">his qualities;</hi>] is a phrase mentioned by Fr in explanation of <foreign lang="ar">رَبَأْتُ فِيهِ</foreign>. (TA voce <foreign lang="ar">رَبَأَ</foreign>, q. v. See also the explanation of <foreign lang="ar">لَأَ خْبُرَنَّ خَبَرَكَ</foreign>, in the first paragraph of art. <foreign lang="ar">خبر</foreign>: and see <foreign lang="ar">غَبَنُوا خَبَرَهَا</foreign>, in art. <foreign lang="ar">غبن</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمْتُ</foreign> is also used in the manner of a verb signifying swearing, or asseveration, so as to have a similar complement; as in the saying, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَلَقَدْ عَلِمْتُ لَتَأْتِيَنَّ عَشِيَّةً</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And I certainly knew that thou wouldst,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">that she would, assuredly come in the evening</hi>]. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">شهد</foreign>.) And <foreign lang="ar">يَعْلَمُ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">God knoweth</hi>] is a form of asseveration. (IAth, TA voce <foreign lang="ar">قَيْرَوَانٌ</foreign>: see an ex. in art. <foreign lang="ar">قير</foreign>.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلُمَ</foreign>, agreeably with what is said in the M, which is <foreign lang="ar">عَلُمَ هُوَ نَفْسُهُ</foreign>, accord. to the K <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ هُوَ فِى نَفْسِهِ</foreign>, but the verb in this case is correctly like <foreign lang="ar">كَرُمَ</foreign>, (TA,) <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, such as is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَالِم</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيم</foreign>; (M, * K, * TA;) meaning <hi rend="ital">he possessed knowledge</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">العِلْم</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">as a faculty firmly rooted in his mind:</hi> (IJ, * TA:) accord. to IB, <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi>   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30340-5" target="تعلّم" n="5" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n30342"/></foreign> [q. v., as intrans.]: and <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, equal to the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عُلَمَآء</foreign> [pl. of <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign> and of <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيمٌ</foreign>]. (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمَهُ فَعَلَمَهُ</foreign>, aor.

                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">عَلُمَ</orth>
                  </form>: see 3.       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمَهُ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">عَلُمَ</orth>
                  </form> and      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar">عَلِمَ</orth>
                  </form>, (K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَلْمٌ</foreign>, (TA.) signifies <hi rend="ital">He marked it;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">وَسَمَهُ</foreign>. (K.) And one says, <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمْتُ عِمَّتِى</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">I wound my turban upon my head with a mark whereby its mode should be known.</hi> (TA.) [See also 4.]       <sense type="A" n="5">-A5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمَ شَفَتَهُ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar">عَلِمَ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَلْمٌ</foreign>, (S,) <hi rend="ital">He slit his</hi> [upper] <hi rend="ital">lip.</hi> (S, K.)       <sense type="A" n="6">-A6-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَلِمَ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">عَلَمَ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb,) <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (a man, S) <hi rend="ital">had a fissure in his upper lip:</hi> (S, Msb, K:) or <hi rend="ital">in one of its two sides.</hi> (K.)    </entryFree>2c:T1202,<entryFree id="n30341" key="علّمهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>2</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">علّمهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, made him to be such as is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَالِم</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيم</foreign>; i. e., <hi rend="ital">made him to possess knowledge</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">العِلْم</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">as a faculty firmly rooted in his mind:</hi> and hence, <hi rend="ital">he taught him.</hi> And it generally has a second objective complement]. You say, <foreign lang="ar">عَلَّمْتُهُ الشَّىْءَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I made him to know,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">taught him, the thing</hi>], in which case the teshdeed is [said to be] not for the purpose of denoting muchness [of the action; but see what follows]; (S;) and <foreign lang="ar">عَلَّمْتُهُ الفَاتِحَةَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I taught him the Opening Chapter of the Kur-án</hi>], and <foreign lang="ar">الصَّنْعَةَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">the art,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">craft</hi>], &amp;c.; inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَعْلِيمٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) and <foreign lang="ar">علّمهُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">العِلْمَ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَعْلِيمٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عِلَّامٌ</foreign>, the latter like <foreign lang="ar">كِذَّابٌ</foreign>; and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-1" target="اعلمهُ" n="1" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>إِيَّاهُ</foreign>; (K;) both, accord. to the K, signifying the same [i. e. <hi rend="ital">he taught him knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">science</hi>]; but Sb makes a distinction between them, saying that <foreign lang="ar">عَلَّمْتُ</foreign> is like <foreign lang="ar">أَذَّنْتُ</foreign>, and that   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-2" target="أَعْلَمْتُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> is like <foreign lang="ar">آذَنْتُ</foreign>; and Er-Rághib says that   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-3" target="الإِعْلَامُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> is particularly applied to quick information; and <foreign lang="ar">التَّعْلِيمُ</foreign> is particularly applied to that which is repeated and much, so that an impression is produced thereby upon the mind of the <foreign lang="ar">مُتَعَلِّم</foreign>: and some say that the latter is <hi rend="ital">the exciting the attention of the mind to the conception of meanings;</hi> and sometimes it is used in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">الإِعْلَام</foreign> when there is in it muchness: (TA:) you say, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-4" target="أَعْلَمْتُهُ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الخَبَرَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بِالخْبَرِ</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">I made known,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">notified,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">announced, to him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">I told him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">I made him to know,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">have knowledge of, the news,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">piece of information; I acquainted him with it; told, informed, apprised, advertised,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">certified, him of it; gave him information, intelligence, notice,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">advice, of it</hi>]: (Msb:) see also 10: [hence the inf. n.   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-5" target="إِعْلَامٌ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> is often used, as a simple subst., to signify <hi rend="ital">a notification, a notice, an announcement,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an advertisement:</hi>] and sometimes   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30341-6" target="اعلم" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> has three objective complements, like <foreign lang="ar">أَرَى</foreign>; as in the saying, <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَمْتُ زَيْدًا عَمْرًا مُنْطَلِقًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I made known,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">to Zeyd that 'Amr was going away</hi>]. (I'Ak p. 117.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  See also 4, in three places.    </entryFree>2d:T56f,<entryFree id="n30341-2" key="عَاْلَمَ">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>3</itype>        
                     <orth lang="ar">عَاْلَمَ</orth>
                  </form>   
      <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمَهُ <ref cref="n30341-2-1" target="فَعَلَمَهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, aor. of the latter      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">عَلُمَ</orth>
                  </form>, means [<hi rend="ital">I contended with him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strove to surpass him, in</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign>,] <hi rend="ital">and I surpassed him in</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">knowledge,</hi> &amp;c.]: (S, K:) [the measure <foreign lang="ar">يَفْعَلُ</foreign>,] and in like manner the measure <foreign lang="ar">يَفْعِلُ</foreign>, in every case of this kind, is changed into <foreign lang="ar">يَفْعُلُ</foreign>: so says Az: [but see 3 in art. <foreign lang="ar">خصم</foreign>:] and Lh mentions the phrase, <foreign lang="ar">مَا كُنْتُ أَرَانِى أَنْ أَعْلُمَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I did not think,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">know, that I should surpass him in knowledge</hi>].                   <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">العَالَمُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, Msb, K, &amp;c.,) said by some to be also pronounced   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30364-1" target="العَالِمُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (MF, TA,) and pronounced by El-Hajjáj with hemz [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">العَأْلَمُ</foreign>], is primarily a name for <hi rend="ital">That by means of which one knows</hi> [a thing]; like as <foreign lang="ar">الخَاتَمُ</foreign> is a name for “ that by means of which one seals ” [a thing]: accord. to some of the expositors of the Kur-án, its predominant application is to <hi rend="ital">that by means of which the Creator is known:</hi> then to <hi rend="ital">the intelligent beings of mankind and of the jinn</hi> or <hi rend="ital">genii:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to mankind and the jinn and the angels:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">mankind</hi> [alone]: Es-Seyyid Esh-Shereef [El- <pb n="2141"/> Jurjánee] adopts the opinion that it is applied to <hi rend="ital">every kind</hi> [of these, so that one says <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ الإِنْسِ</foreign> (which may be rendered <hi rend="ital">the world of mankind</hi>) and <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ الجِنِّ</foreign> (<hi rend="ital">the world of the jinn</hi> or <hi rend="ital">genii</hi>) and <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ المَلَائِكَةِ</foreign> (<hi rend="ital">the world of the angels</hi>), all of which phrases are of frequent occurrence], and to <hi rend="ital">the kinds</hi> [thereof] <hi rend="ital">collectively:</hi> (TA:) or it signifies <foreign lang="ar">الخَلْقُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">the creation,</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">the beings,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">things, that are created</hi>], (S, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">altogether</hi> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">all the created beings</hi> or <hi rend="ital">things,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">all creatures</hi>]: (K:) or, as some say, peculiarly, <hi rend="ital">the intelligent creatures:</hi> (Msb:) or <hi rend="ital">what the cavity</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">belly</hi>) <hi rend="ital">of the celestial sphere comprises,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">of substances and accidents:</hi> (TA:) [it may often be rendered <hi rend="ital">the world,</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">the universe;</hi> and as meaning <hi rend="ital">the earth with all its inhabitants and other appertenances;</hi> and in more restricted senses, as instanced above: and one says <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ الحَيَوَانِ</foreign> meaning <hi rend="ital">the animal kingdom,</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ النَّبَات</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the vegetable kingdom,</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمُ المَعَادِنِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the mineral kingdom:</hi>] Jaafar Es-Sádik says that the <foreign lang="ar">عَالَم</foreign> is twofold: namely, <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُ الكَبِيرُ</foreign>, which is <hi rend="ital">the celestial sphere with what is within it;</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُ الصَّغِيرُ</foreign>, which is <hi rend="ital">man, as being</hi> [<hi rend="ital">a microcosm,</hi> i. e.] <hi rend="ital">an epitome of all that is in the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كَبِير</foreign>: and Zj says that <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُ</foreign> has no literal sing., because it is [significant of] a plurality [of classes] of diverse things; and if made a sing. of one of them, it is [significant of] a plurality of congruous things: (TA:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُونَ</foreign> (S, M, Msb, K, &amp;c.) and <foreign lang="ar">العَوَالِمُ</foreign>: (S, TA:) and the sing. is [said to be] the only instance of a word of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَاعَلٌ</foreign> having a pl. formed with <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign>, (ISd, K, TA,) except <foreign lang="ar">يَاسَمٌ</foreign>: (K, TA:) [but see this latter word:] <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُونَ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">the</hi> [<hi rend="ital">several</hi>] <hi rend="ital">sorts of created beings</hi> or <hi rend="ital">things:</hi> (S:) [or <hi rend="ital">all the sorts thereof:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the beings of the universe,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of the whole world:</hi>] it has this form because it includes mankind: or because it denotes particularly <hi rend="ital">the sorts of created beings consisting of the angels and the jinn and mankind, exclusively of others:</hi> I'Ab is related to have explained <foreign lang="ar">رَبُّ العَالَمِينَ</foreign> as meaning <hi rend="ital">the Lord of the jinn,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">genii, and of mankind:</hi> Katádeh says, <hi rend="ital">the Lord of all the created beings:</hi> but accord. to Az, the correctness of the explanation of I'Ab is shown by the saying in the beginning of ch. xxv. of the Kur-án that the Prophet was to be a <foreign lang="ar">نَذِير</foreign> [or warner] <foreign lang="ar">لِلْعَالَمِينَ</foreign>; and he was not a <foreign lang="ar">نذير</foreign> to the beasts, nor to the angels, though all of them are the creatures of God; but only to the jinn, or genii, and mankind. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَالَمٌ</foreign> is also <hi rend="ital">syn. with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قَرْنٌ</foreign> [as meaning <hi rend="ital">A generation of mankind;</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">people of one time</hi>]. (O, voce <foreign lang="ar">طَبَقٌ</foreign>, q. v.)    </entryFree>36:T969,<entryFree id="n30365" key="عَالِمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30365-1" target="عَلِيمٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30357"/></foreign> signify the same, (IJ, Msb, K, *) as epithets applied to a man; (K;) i. e. <hi rend="ital">Possessing the attribute of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عِلْم</foreign> (IJ, Msb, TA) <hi rend="ital">as a faculty firmly rooted in the mind;</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">learned;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">versed in science and literature;</hi>] the former being used in [what is more properly] the sense of the latter; (IJ, TA;) which is an intensive epithet: (TA:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">عُلَمَآءُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُلَّامٌ</foreign>, (K,) the latter of which is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign>; (IB, TA;) the former being [properly] pl. of <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيمٌ</foreign>; and <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمُونَ</foreign> is [a] pl. of <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) [but] <foreign lang="ar">عُلَمَآءُ</foreign> is used as a pl. of both, (IJ, TA,) and by him who says only <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign> [as the sing.], (Sb, TA;) because <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign> is used in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيمٌ</foreign>: to him who is entering upon the study of <foreign lang="ar">العِلْم</foreign>, the epithet   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30365-2" target="مُتَعَلِّمٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30377"/></foreign> [which may generally be rendered <hi rend="ital">learning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a learner,</hi>] is applied; not <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign>. (IJ, TA.) <foreign lang="ar">عَالِمٌ</foreign> is also expl. as signifying One <hi rend="ital">who does according to his knowledge.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيمٌ</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَمُ</foreign>.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  And see <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُ</foreign>.    </entryFree>37:Tc5e,<entryFree id="n30366" key="عَيْلَمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَيْلَمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A well having much water:</hi> (S, K:) or <hi rend="ital">of which the water is salt:</hi> (K:) and <hi rend="ital">a wide well:</hi> and sometimes a man was reviled by the saying, <foreign lang="ar">يَا ٱبْنَ العَيْلَمِ</foreign>, referring to the width of his mother [in respect of the <foreign lang="ar">فَرْج</foreign>]: (TA:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">عَيَالِمُ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">عَيَالِيمُ</foreign>. (S, accord. to different copies: in the TA, in this instance, the latter.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">sea:</hi> (S, K:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">عَيَالِمُ</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">water upon which is the earth:</hi> (S, K:) or <hi rend="ital">water concealed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">covered, in the earth;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beneath layers,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strata, of earth;</hi> mentioned by Kr: (TA:) [<foreign lang="ar">عَيْلَمُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">المَآءِ</foreign> occurs in the JK and TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">خسف</foreign>, and is there plainly shown to mean <hi rend="ital">the water that is beneath a mountain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stratum of rock:</hi> (see also <foreign lang="ar">غَيِّثٌ</foreign>: and see <foreign lang="ar">غَيْلَمٌ</foreign>:) and it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">المَأءُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">العَيْلَمُ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">copious water.</hi> (Ham p. 750.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">A large cooking-pot.</hi> (T, TA voce <foreign lang="ar">هِلْجَابٌ</foreign>.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Plump,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">soft, tender,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">delicate.</hi> (S, K.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">frog.</hi> (AAF, K. [This meaning is also assigned to <foreign lang="ar">غَيْلَمٌ</foreign>.])          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi>   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30366-1" target="عَيْلَامٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n30367"/></foreign>; (K;) which signifies <hi rend="ital">A male hyena;</hi> (S, K;) occurring in a trad. (<foreign lang="ar">خَبَر</foreign>) respecting Abraham, relating that he will take up his father to pass with him the [bridge called] <foreign lang="ar">صِرَاط</foreign>, and will look at him, and lo, he will be <foreign lang="ar">عَيْلَامٌ أَمْدَرُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">a male hyena inflated in the sides, big in the belly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">having his sides defiled with earth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dust</hi>]. (TA.)    </entryFree>38:Tdd8,<entryFree id="n30371" key="مَعْلَمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مَعْلَمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَظِنَّةٌ</foreign>; <foreign lang="ar">مَعْلَمُ الشَّىْءِ</foreign> signifying <foreign lang="ar">مَظِنَّتُهُ</foreign>; (K, TA;) as meaning <hi rend="ital">The place in which is known the existence of the thing:</hi> (Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">ظن</foreign>:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">مَعَالِمُ</foreign>; (TA;) which is the <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَجَاهِلُ</foreign>, pl. of <foreign lang="ar">مَجْهَلٌ</foreign> [q. v.] as applied to a land; meaning <hi rend="ital">in which are signs of the way.</hi> (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">جهل</foreign>.) And hence, [<hi rend="ital">A person in whom is known the existence</hi> of a quality &amp;c.:] one says, <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ مَعْلَمٌ لِلْخَيْرِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He is one in whom good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goodness, is known to be</hi>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">A thing,</hi> (K,) or <hi rend="ital">a mark, trace,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">track,</hi> (S, TA,) <hi rend="ital">by which one guides himself,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">is guided,</hi> (S, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">to the road,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">way;</hi> (S, TA;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30371-1" target="عُلَّامَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30363"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n30371-2" target="عَلْمٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n30346"/></foreign>: (K: [in several copies of which, in all as far as I know, <foreign lang="ar">وَالعَلْمُ</foreign> is here put in the place of <foreign lang="ar">والعَلْمِ</foreign>; whereby <foreign lang="ar">العَلْمُ</foreign> is made to be syn. with <foreign lang="ar">العَالَمُ</foreign>: but accord. to SM, it is syn. with <foreign lang="ar">المَعْلَمُ</foreign>, as is shown by what here follows:]) and hence a reading in the Kur [xliii. 61],   
      <foreign lang="ar">وَإِنَّهُ <ref cref="n30371-3" target="لَعَلْمٌ" n="3" lang="ar" type="7" subtype="WOTF"/> لِلسَّاعَةِ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">And verily he,</hi> i. e. Jesus, by his appearing, and descending to the earth, shall be <hi rend="ital">a sign</hi> of the approach <hi rend="ital">of the hour</hi> [of resurrection]: it is also said, in a trad., that on the day of resurrection there shall not be a <foreign lang="ar">مَعْلَم</foreign> for any one: and the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">مَعَالِمُ</foreign>. (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">مَعْلَمُ الطِّرِيقِ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">The indication,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">indicator, of the road,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">way.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [And hence it signifies likewise <hi rend="ital">An indication,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a symptom,</hi> of anything; like <foreign lang="ar">عَلَامَةٌ</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">عَلَمٌ</foreign>, last quarter. your children, God commands you that a son should have the equivalent share of two daughters. If there are only daughters, two or more should share two-thirds of the inheritance, if one, she should have half. Parents inherit a sixth each if the deceased leaves children; if he leaves no children and his parents are his sole heirs, his mother has a third, unless he has brothers, in which case she has a sixth. &#91;In all cases, the distribution comes&#93; after payment of any bequests or debts.
